title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: intervalpsych R package analyzing interval responses psychometrics. implements Interval Consensus Model (ICM) using Stan Bayesian estimation, along transformation visualization functions interval-valued data.

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Run all tests Rscript -e "devtools::test()"  # Run specific test file Rscript -e "testthat::test_file('tests/testthat/test-fit_icm.R')"  # Check package Rscript -e "devtools::check()"

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Install package locally Rscript -e "devtools::install()"  # Build package Rscript -e "devtools::build()"  # Load package for development Rscript -e "devtools::load_all()"

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Generate documentation Rscript -e "devtools::document()"  # Build pkgdown site Rscript -e "pkgdown::build_site()"  # Build vignettes Rscript -e "devtools::build_vignettes()"

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses vignette-less articles workflow pkgdown described : https://fml-fam.github.io/blog/2020/06/23/vignette-less-articles--pkgdown/ Key Components: - Source vignettes stored vignettes/src/ directory - vignettes/ directory added .Rbuildignore - Articles built manually using rmarkdown::render() specific format settings - Provides complete control documents rebuilt Build Process: Manual Vignette Building:
code: # Rebuild vignette source files (if using Makefile) make vignettes  # Generate pkgdown articles make articles    # Generate full site documentation make docs # Example render configuration used in this package rmarkdown::render(   input = "vignettes/src/_01-Interval-Consensus-Model.Rmd",   output_format = rmarkdown::md_document(     variant = "gfm",     preserve_yaml = TRUE,     ext = ".Rmd"   ) )

title: CLAUDE.md
text: icm_ilr.stan: ICM Isometric Log-Ratio transformation icm_slr.stan: ICM Sum Log-Ratio transformation include transformation functions simplex bivariate normal representations Supports ILR SLR link functions via link parameter Returns icm_stanfit objects components: stan_model, stan_fit, stan_data, item_labels Comprehensive input validation data checking ilr()/inv_ilr(): Isometric log-ratio transformations slr()/inv_slr(): Sum log-ratio transformations itvl_to_splx()/splx_to_itvl(): Interval bounds simplex conversions remove_zeros(): Handle zero components simplex data padding extract_consensus() (R/extract_consensus.R): Extract consensus intervals fitted models summary.icm_stanfit() (R/summary_icm_stanfit.R): Summary method model objects plot_consensus(): Plot consensus intervals fitted ICM models plot.icm_stanfit(): S3 method plotting model results plot_intervals(): General interval plotting plot_intervals_cumulative(): Cumulative interval plots theme_icm(): Custom ggplot2 theme check_simplex(): Validate simplex constraints check_bvn(): Validate bivariate normal vectors check_interval_bounds(): Validate interval bounds data Stan Integration (R/stanmodels.R, src/): Generated Stan model objects compiled C++ code

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Raw interval data → Simplex representation (itvl_to_splx()) Remove zero components (remove_zeros()) needed Simplex data → ILR/SLR transformation → Bayesian estimation via Stan (fit_icm()) Extract consensus intervals (extract_consensus()) Visualization (plot_consensus()) summarization (summary())

title: CLAUDE.md
text: fit_icm(df_simplex, id_person, id_item, item_labels = NULL, link = "ilr", padding = 0, iter_sampling = 500, iter_warmup = 500, n_chains = 4, n_cores = 1, adapt_delta = 0.9, ...) extract_consensus(icm_stanfit, print_summary = TRUE) plot_consensus(icm_stanfit, method = "median_bounds", CI = 0.95)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Stan ecosystem: rstan, rstantools, StanHeaders, RcppParallel Bayesian modeling Data manipulation: dplyr, purrr data processing Visualization: ggplot2, ggdist, ggokabeito plotting Statistical: posterior post-processing R Core: methods, Rcpp, RcppEigen, BH C++ integration Suggested: testthat (>= 3.0.0) testing

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Uses testthat (edition 3) comprehensive test coverage. Test files tests/testthat/ follow pattern test-*.R matching source files R/: test-fit_icm.R: Model fitting synthetic data test-transformation_functions.R: Log-ratio interval transformations test-extract_consensus.R: Consensus interval extraction test-plot_*.R: Visualization functions test-check_data_format.R: Input validation test-remove_zeros.R: Zero handling test-summary_icm_stanfit.R: Model summarization test-theme_icm.R: Custom plotting theme

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R/: Main package functions (14 files) inst/stan/: Stan model files (icm_ilr.stan, icm_slr.stan) src/: Generated C++ code Stan models RcppExports data/: Example datasets (quantifiers.rda, quantifiers_original.rds) man/: Generated documentation files vignettes/src/: Package vignette (_01-Interval-Consensus-Model.Rmd) tests/testthat/: Unit tests (11 test files) docs/: Generated pkgdown documentation website

title: CLAUDE.md
text: modifying Stan models: 1. Edit files inst/stan/ directory 2. Recompile devtools::load_all() reinstall package 3. Stan models automatically compiled package load 4. Access compiled model objects via stanmodels$icm_ilr stanmodels$icm_slr 5. models support padding zero-component handling 6. Models include posterior predictive checks consensus parameter extraction

title: CLAUDE.md
text: build articles pkgdown website, used workflow: https://fml-fam.github.io/blog/2020/06/23/vignette-less-articles--pkgdown/ run Makefile “docs” directory build articles pkgdown website

title: Authors and Citation
text: Matthias Kloft. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Björn S. Siepe. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kloft M, Siepe B (2025). intervalpsych: Analyzing Interval Data Psychometrics. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://matthiaskloft.github.io/intervalpsych/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {intervalpsych: Analyzing Interval Data in Psychometrics},   author = {Matthias Kloft and Björn S. Siepe},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://matthiaskloft.github.io/intervalpsych/}, }

title: Analyzing Interval Data in Psychometrics
text: intervalpsych package provides toolbox analysis interval responses psychometrics similar disciplines. Interval responses can used represent uncertainty variability responses survey items, example. Besides transformation plotting function, package also contains wrapper estimate Interval Consensus Model (ICM; Kloft, Siepe & Heck, 2024) probabilistic programming language Stan. Results model can visualized summarized using functions provided package.

title: Analyzing Interval Data in Psychometrics
text: can install released version intervalpsych CRAN : can install latest development version intervalpsych GitHub :
code: install.packages("intervalpsych") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("matthiaskloft/intervalpsych")

what: Extract consensus intervals from ICM Stan Fit Object — extract_consensus
title: Extract consensus intervals from ICM Stan Fit Object — extract_consensus
text: function extracts parameter estimates consensus intervals fitted Interval Consensus Model Stan fit object class icm_stanfit.

title: Extract consensus intervals from ICM Stan Fit Object — extract_consensus
code: extract_consensus(icm_stanfit, print_summary = TRUE)

title: Extract consensus intervals from ICM Stan Fit Object — extract_consensus
text: icm_stanfit object class icm_stanfit containing fitted Stan model. print_summary logical value indicating whether print summary extracted parameters. Default TRUE.

title: Extract consensus intervals from ICM Stan Fit Object — extract_consensus
text: list containing: df_rvar data frame extracted posterior samples random variable datatype (see posterior::rvar()). summary summary data frame median credible intervals extracted parameters.

title: Extract consensus intervals from ICM Stan Fit Object — extract_consensus
text: function extracts parameter estimates consensus intervals fitted Interval Consensus Model Stan fit object class icm_stanfit.

title: Extract consensus intervals from ICM Stan Fit Object — extract_consensus
code: # \donttest{ # Create minimal example data df_simplex <- data.frame(   x1 = c(0.3, 0.4, 0.2, 0.5),   x2 = c(0.3, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2),   x3 = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.4, 0.3) ) id_person <- c(1, 1, 2, 2) id_item <- c(1, 2, 1, 2)  # Fit ICM model fit <- fit_icm(df_simplex, id_person, id_item, chains = 1,                iter_sampling = 100, iter_warmup = 100) #>  #> SAMPLING FOR MODEL 'icm_ilr' NOW (CHAIN 1). #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Gradient evaluation took 5.4e-05 seconds #> Chain 1: 1000 transitions using 10 leapfrog steps per transition would take 0.54 seconds. #> Chain 1: Adjust your expectations accordingly! #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: WARNING: There aren't enough warmup iterations to fit the #> Chain 1:          three stages of adaptation as currently configured. #> Chain 1:          Reducing each adaptation stage to 15%/75%/10% of #> Chain 1:          the given number of warmup iterations: #> Chain 1:            init_buffer = 15 #> Chain 1:            adapt_window = 75 #> Chain 1:            term_buffer = 10 #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Iteration:   1 / 200 [  0%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  20 / 200 [ 10%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  40 / 200 [ 20%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  60 / 200 [ 30%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  80 / 200 [ 40%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 100 / 200 [ 50%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 101 / 200 [ 50%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 120 / 200 [ 60%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 140 / 200 [ 70%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 160 / 200 [ 80%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 180 / 200 [ 90%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 200 / 200 [100%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  Elapsed Time: 0.232 seconds (Warm-up) #> Chain 1:                0.19 seconds (Sampling) #> Chain 1:                0.422 seconds (Total) #> Chain 1:  #> Warning: There were 9 divergent transitions after warmup. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#divergent-transitions-after-warmup #> to find out why this is a problem and how to eliminate them. #> Warning: Examine the pairs() plot to diagnose sampling problems #> Warning: The largest R-hat is 1.08, indicating chains have not mixed. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#r-hat #> Warning: Bulk Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior means and medians may be unreliable. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#bulk-ess #> Warning: Tail Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior variances and tail quantiles may be unreliable. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#tail-ess  # Extract consensus intervals consensus <- extract_consensus(fit) #>   T_L_median T_L_CI_025 T_L_CI_975 T_U_median T_U_CI_025 T_U_CI_975 #> 1       0.22       0.02       0.42       0.57       0.23       0.77 #> 2       0.44       0.24       0.69       0.65       0.46       0.85 # }

what: Fit the Interval Consensus Model — fit_icm
title: Fit the Interval Consensus Model — fit_icm
text: function fits Interval Consensus Model (ICM, Kloft et al., 2024) using Stan.

title: Fit the Interval Consensus Model — fit_icm
code: fit_icm(   df_simplex,   id_person,   id_item,   item_labels = NULL,   link = "ilr",   padding = 0,   iter_sampling = 500,   iter_warmup = 500,   n_chains = 4,   n_cores = 1,   adapt_delta = 0.9,   ... )

title: Fit the Interval Consensus Model — fit_icm
text: df_simplex dataframe containing simplex data. id_person vector person indices. id_item vector item indices. item_labels vector item labels. Can long format matching id_item vector unique labels ascending order. Default NULL. link character string specifying link function. Options "ilr" (Isometric Log-Ratio) "slr" (Sum Log-Ratio). See also ilr() slr() details. Default "ilr". padding Padding constant used remove zero-components simplex. Default 0. model reverse padding transforming results back original interval response scale. See also remove_zeros() details. iter_sampling integer specifying number sampling iterations used rstan::sampling() Default 500. iter_warmup integer specifying number warmup iterations used rstan::sampling() Default 500. n_chains integer specifying number Markov chains used rstan::sampling() Default 4. n_cores integer specifying number cores use used rstan::sampling() Default 1. adapt_delta numeric value specifying target acceptance rate used rstan::sampling() Default 0.9. ... Additional arguments passed rstan::sampling() function.

title: Fit the Interval Consensus Model — fit_icm
text: fitted Stan model object class icm_stanfit containing following components: stan_model compiled Stan model object. stan_fit fitted Stan model posterior samples model parameters (see ). stan_data data list passed Stan. item_labels vector item labels. stan_fit component contains posterior samples ICM parameters: Person Parameters: E_loc - Person proficiency location E_wid - Person proficiency width a_loc - Person scaling bias location b_loc - Person shifting bias location b_wid - Person shifting bias width rho_E - Correlation person proficiencies location width Item Parameters: Tr_loc - Item consensus location logit-transformed space Tr_wid - Item consensus width logit-transformed space Tr_loc_splx - Item consensus location simplex space Tr_wid_splx - Item consensus width simplex space Tr_L - Item consensus lower bound Tr_U - Item consensus upper bound Tr_splx - Item consensus simplex representation lambda_loc - Item discernibility location lambda_wid - Item discernibility width omega - Item residual correlations location width rho_lambda - Correlation item discernibilities location width Hyperparameters: mu_E - Means person proficiencies sigma_I - Standard deviations person parameters sigma_lambda - Standard deviations item discernibilities Posterior Predictive Checks: Y_ppc_loc - Predicted responses location logit-transformed space Y_ppc_wid - Predicted responses width logit-transformed space Y_ppc_splx - Predicted responses simplex space Y_ppc_loc_splx - Predicted location responses simplex space (mean lower upper bound) Y_ppc_wid_splx - Predicted width responses simplex space

title: Fit the Interval Consensus Model — fit_icm
text: Kloft, M., Siepe, B. S., & Heck, D. W. (2024). Interval Truth Model: Consensus Model Continuous Bounded Interval Responses. doi:10.31234/osf.io/dzvw2

title: Fit the Interval Consensus Model — fit_icm
code: # \donttest{ # Create minimal example data df_simplex <- data.frame(   x1 = c(0.3, 0.4, 0.2, 0.5),   x2 = c(0.3, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2),   x3 = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.4, 0.3) ) id_person <- c(1, 1, 2, 2) id_item <- c(1, 2, 1, 2)  # Fit ICM model (reduce iterations for faster example) fit <- fit_icm(df_simplex, id_person, id_item, n_chains = 1,                iter_sampling = 100, iter_warmup = 100) #>  #> SAMPLING FOR MODEL 'icm_ilr' NOW (CHAIN 1). #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Gradient evaluation took 4.1e-05 seconds #> Chain 1: 1000 transitions using 10 leapfrog steps per transition would take 0.41 seconds. #> Chain 1: Adjust your expectations accordingly! #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: WARNING: There aren't enough warmup iterations to fit the #> Chain 1:          three stages of adaptation as currently configured. #> Chain 1:          Reducing each adaptation stage to 15%/75%/10% of #> Chain 1:          the given number of warmup iterations: #> Chain 1:            init_buffer = 15 #> Chain 1:            adapt_window = 75 #> Chain 1:            term_buffer = 10 #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Iteration:   1 / 200 [  0%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  20 / 200 [ 10%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  40 / 200 [ 20%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  60 / 200 [ 30%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  80 / 200 [ 40%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 100 / 200 [ 50%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 101 / 200 [ 50%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 120 / 200 [ 60%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 140 / 200 [ 70%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 160 / 200 [ 80%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 180 / 200 [ 90%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 200 / 200 [100%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  Elapsed Time: 0.145 seconds (Warm-up) #> Chain 1:                0.108 seconds (Sampling) #> Chain 1:                0.253 seconds (Total) #> Chain 1:  #> Warning: There were 3 divergent transitions after warmup. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#divergent-transitions-after-warmup #> to find out why this is a problem and how to eliminate them. #> Warning: Examine the pairs() plot to diagnose sampling problems #> Warning: The largest R-hat is 1.13, indicating chains have not mixed. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#r-hat #> Warning: Bulk Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior means and medians may be unreliable. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#bulk-ess #> Warning: Tail Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior variances and tail quantiles may be unreliable. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#tail-ess  # Print summary of the fit summary(fit) #>   T_L_median T_L_CI_025 T_L_CI_975 T_U_median T_U_CI_025 T_U_CI_975 #> 1  0.1935564 0.07474671  0.4182611  0.5627983  0.2197616  0.7832223 #> 2  0.4289527 0.20590911  0.6126743  0.6611914  0.4617445  0.8037751 # }

what: Inverse Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — inv_log_ratio_transformations
title: Inverse Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — inv_log_ratio_transformations
text: Transform unbounded data back simplex space using either Isometric Log-Ratio (ILR) Sum Log-Ratio (SLR) inverse transformations described Smithson & Broomell (2024). transformations inverse ilr() slr() transformations. Inverse ILR inverse ILR transformation equations : $$x_1 = \frac{\exp(\sqrt{2} x_{loc})}{\exp(\sqrt{2} x_{loc}) + \exp(\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} x_{wid} + \frac{x_{loc}}{\sqrt{2}}) + 1}$$ $$x_2 = \frac{\exp(\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} x_{wid} + \frac{x_{loc}}{\sqrt{2}})}{\exp(\sqrt{2} x_{loc}) + \exp(\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} x_{wid} + \frac{x_{loc}}{\sqrt{2}}) + 1}$$ $$x_3 = \frac{1}{\exp(\sqrt{2} x_{loc}) + \exp(\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} x_{wid} + \frac{x_{loc}}{\sqrt{2}}) + 1}$$ Inverse SLR inverse SLR transformation equations : $$x_1 = \frac{\exp(x_{loc})}{(\exp(x_{loc}) + 1)(\exp(x_{wid}) + 1)}$$ $$x_2 = \frac{\exp(x_{wid})}{\exp(x_{wid}) + 1}$$ $$x_3 = \frac{1}{(\exp(x_{loc}) + 1)(\exp(x_{wid}) + 1)}$$ \((x_{loc}, x_{wid})\) unbounded interval location width \((x_1, x_2, x_3)\) resulting interval response simplex format.

title: Inverse Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — inv_log_ratio_transformations
code: inv_ilr(bvn)  inv_slr(bvn)

title: Inverse Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — inv_log_ratio_transformations
text: bvn numeric vector containing unbounded interval location width dataframe rows consists vector.

title: Inverse Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — inv_log_ratio_transformations
text: numeric vector containing 2-simplex dataframe rows consists vector.

title: Inverse Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — inv_log_ratio_transformations
text: Smithson, M., & Broomell, S. B. (2024). Compositional data analysis tutorial. Psychological Methods, 29(2), 362–378.

title: Inverse Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — inv_log_ratio_transformations
code: # Generate some unbounded data bvn <- data.frame(rbind(c(0, .2), c(-2, .4)))  # Inverse ILR transformation inv_ilr(bvn) #>          x_1       x_2       x_3 #> 1 0.30510538 0.3897892 0.3051054 #> 2 0.04059715 0.2725466 0.6868563  # Inverse SLR transformation inv_slr(bvn) #>         x_1       x_2       x_3 #> 1 0.2250830 0.5498340 0.2250830 #> 2 0.0478376 0.5986877 0.3534747

what: Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — log_ratio_transformations
title: Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — log_ratio_transformations
text: Transform interval responses simplex space unbounded space using either Isometric Log-Ratio (ILR) Sum Log-Ratio (SLR) transformation described Smithson & Broomell (2024). transformations preserve dimensional conceptualization interval responses terms location width. See also inv_ilr(), inv_slr() inverse transformations. ILR ILR transformation equations : $$x_{loc} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{2}} \log\left(\frac{x_1}{x_3}\right)$$ $$x_{wid} = \sqrt{\frac{2}{3}} \log\left(\frac{x_2}{\sqrt{x_1 x_3}}\right)$$ SLR SLR transformation equations : $$x_{loc} = \log\left(\frac{x_1}{x_3}\right)$$ $$x_{wid} = \log\left(\frac{x_2}{x_1 + x_3}\right)$$ \((x_1, x_2, x_3)\) interval response simplex format \((x_{loc}, x_{wid})\) transformed values representing unbounded location width.

title: Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — log_ratio_transformations
code: ilr(simplex)  slr(simplex)

title: Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — log_ratio_transformations
text: simplex numeric vector 2-simplex (3 elements sum 1) dataframe rows 2-simplex

title: Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — log_ratio_transformations
text: numeric vector 2 elements, unbounded interval location width, dataframe rows numeric vector 2 elements

title: Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — log_ratio_transformations
text: Smithson, M., & Broomell, S. B. (2024). Compositional data analysis tutorial. Psychological Methods, 29(2), 362–378.

title: Log-Ratio transformations for interval responses — log_ratio_transformations
code: # Generate some simplex data simplex <- data.frame(rbind(c(.1, .2, .7), c(.4, .5, .1)))  # ILR transformation ilr(simplex) #>        x_loc      x_wid #> 1 -1.3759663 -0.2284622 #> 2  0.9802581  0.7481482  # SLR transformation slr(simplex) #>       x_loc     x_wid #> 1 -1.945910 -1.386294 #> 2  1.386294  0.000000

code: # \donttest{ # Create minimal example data df_simplex <- data.frame(   x1 = c(0.3, 0.4, 0.2, 0.5),   x2 = c(0.3, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2),   x3 = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.4, 0.3) ) id_person <- c(1, 1, 2, 2) id_item <- c(1, 2, 1, 2)  # Fit ICM model fit <- fit_icm(df_simplex, id_person, id_item, n_chains = 1,                iter_sampling = 100, iter_warmup = 100) #>  #> SAMPLING FOR MODEL 'icm_ilr' NOW (CHAIN 1). #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Gradient evaluation took 5.8e-05 seconds #> Chain 1: 1000 transitions using 10 leapfrog steps per transition would take 0.58 seconds. #> Chain 1: Adjust your expectations accordingly! #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: WARNING: There aren't enough warmup iterations to fit the #> Chain 1:          three stages of adaptation as currently configured. #> Chain 1:          Reducing each adaptation stage to 15%/75%/10% of #> Chain 1:          the given number of warmup iterations: #> Chain 1:            init_buffer = 15 #> Chain 1:            adapt_window = 75 #> Chain 1:            term_buffer = 10 #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Iteration:   1 / 200 [  0%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  20 / 200 [ 10%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  40 / 200 [ 20%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  60 / 200 [ 30%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  80 / 200 [ 40%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 100 / 200 [ 50%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 101 / 200 [ 50%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 120 / 200 [ 60%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 140 / 200 [ 70%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 160 / 200 [ 80%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 180 / 200 [ 90%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 200 / 200 [100%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  Elapsed Time: 0.186 seconds (Warm-up) #> Chain 1:                0.202 seconds (Sampling) #> Chain 1:                0.388 seconds (Total) #> Chain 1:  #> Warning: There were 6 divergent transitions after warmup. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#divergent-transitions-after-warmup #> to find out why this is a problem and how to eliminate them. #> Warning: Examine the pairs() plot to diagnose sampling problems #> Warning: The largest R-hat is 1.09, indicating chains have not mixed. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#r-hat #> Warning: Bulk Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior means and medians may be unreliable. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#bulk-ess #> Warning: Tail Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior variances and tail quantiles may be unreliable. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#tail-ess  # Plot using S3 method plot(fit)  # }

title: Plot ICM Consensus Intervals — plot_consensus

title: Plot ICM Consensus Intervals — plot_consensus
text: icm_stanfit object class 'icm_stanfit' containing Stanfit results. method character string specifying plotting method. Options "median_bounds" (default) "draws_distribution". CI numeric value specifying confidence interval "draws_distribution" method. Default 0.95. can also vector length 2 multiple confidence intervals.

title: Plot ICM Consensus Intervals — plot_consensus
text: ggplot2 object representing interval plot.

title: Plot ICM Consensus Intervals — plot_consensus
text: function checks input object class 'icm_stanfit'. extracts draws lower upper bounds (T_L T_U) Stanfit object. method "median_bounds", function calculates median lower upper bounds generates interval plot using medians. method "draws_distribution", function checks number draws warns less 1000. computes consensus distribution item generates gradient interval plot.

title: Plot ICM Consensus Intervals — plot_consensus

title: Plot Cumulative Intervals — plot_intervals_cumulative

Default NA. min minimum value x-axis. max maximum value x-axis. facet_wrap logical value indicating whether use facet wrapping. Default NULL. weighted optional vector weights intervals. show_quantiles logical value indicating whether show quantiles plot. Default TRUE. ncol number columns facet wrapping. Default 3.

code: # Example data lower_bounds <- c(0.01, 0.3, 0.02, 0.4) upper_bounds <- c(0.5, 0.96, 0.6, 0.8) cluster_ids <- c(1, 1, 2, 2) truth_values <- c(0.3, 0.3, 0.6, 0.6)  # Create cumulative interval plot plot_intervals_cumulative(   lower = lower_bounds,   upper = upper_bounds,   cluster_id = cluster_ids,   truth = truth_values,   min = 0,   max = 1,   weighted = FALSE ) #> Joining with `by = join_by(cluster_id)`

code: # \donttest{ # Create minimal example data df_simplex <- data.frame(   x1 = c(0.3, 0.4, 0.2, 0.5),   x2 = c(0.3, 0.2, 0.4, 0.2),   x3 = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.4, 0.3) ) id_person <- c(1, 1, 2, 2) id_item <- c(1, 2, 1, 2)  # Fit ICM model fit <- fit_icm(df_simplex, id_person, id_item, n_chains = 1,                iter_sampling = 100, iter_warmup = 100) #>  #> SAMPLING FOR MODEL 'icm_ilr' NOW (CHAIN 1). #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Gradient evaluation took 4.2e-05 seconds #> Chain 1: 1000 transitions using 10 leapfrog steps per transition would take 0.42 seconds. #> Chain 1: Adjust your expectations accordingly! #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: WARNING: There aren't enough warmup iterations to fit the #> Chain 1:          three stages of adaptation as currently configured. #> Chain 1:          Reducing each adaptation stage to 15%/75%/10% of #> Chain 1:          the given number of warmup iterations: #> Chain 1:            init_buffer = 15 #> Chain 1:            adapt_window = 75 #> Chain 1:            term_buffer = 10 #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Iteration:   1 / 200 [  0%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  20 / 200 [ 10%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  40 / 200 [ 20%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  60 / 200 [ 30%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  80 / 200 [ 40%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 100 / 200 [ 50%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 101 / 200 [ 50%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 120 / 200 [ 60%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 140 / 200 [ 70%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 160 / 200 [ 80%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 180 / 200 [ 90%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 200 / 200 [100%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  Elapsed Time: 0.123 seconds (Warm-up) #> Chain 1:                0.106 seconds (Sampling) #> Chain 1:                0.229 seconds (Total) #> Chain 1:  #> Warning: There were 3 divergent transitions after warmup. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#divergent-transitions-after-warmup #> to find out why this is a problem and how to eliminate them. #> Warning: Examine the pairs() plot to diagnose sampling problems #> Warning: The largest R-hat is 1.07, indicating chains have not mixed. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#r-hat #> Warning: Bulk Effective Samples Size (ESS) is too low, indicating posterior means and medians may be unreliable. #> Running the chains for more iterations may help. See #> https://mc-stan.org/misc/warnings.html#tail-ess  # Get summary summary(fit) #>   T_L_median T_L_CI_025 T_L_CI_975 T_U_median T_U_CI_025 T_U_CI_975 #> 1  0.2221595 0.07444702  0.5376368  0.5685477  0.2690143  0.8265028 #> 2  0.4153712 0.21775299  0.7183315  0.6509958  0.4386705  0.8860591 # }

what: Custom ggplot2 Theme for intervalpsych — theme_icm
title: Custom ggplot2 Theme for intervalpsych — theme_icm
text: function creates custom ggplot2 theme intervalpsych visualizations.

title: Custom ggplot2 Theme for intervalpsych — theme_icm
code: theme_icm(hide_axis_text_y = FALSE, base_size = 12)

title: Custom ggplot2 Theme for intervalpsych — theme_icm
text: hide_axis_text_y Logical. TRUE, y-axis text ticks hidden. Default FALSE. base_size Numeric. Base font size theme. Default 12.

title: Custom ggplot2 Theme for intervalpsych — theme_icm
text: ggplot2 theme object.

title: Custom ggplot2 Theme for intervalpsych — theme_icm
code: # Create sample interval data df_intervals <- data.frame(   lower = c(0.1, 0.3, 0.2, 0.4),   upper = c(0.5, 0.7, 0.6, 0.8) ) item_labels <- c("Item A", "Item B", "Item C", "Item D")  # Basic usage plot_intervals(df_intervals, item_labels) +   theme_icm()   # Hide y-axis text plot_intervals(df_intervals, item_labels) +   theme_icm(hide_axis_text_y = TRUE)   # Custom base size plot_intervals(df_intervals, item_labels) +   theme_icm(base_size = 14)

title: intervalpsych 0.1.0
text: Initial CRAN submission. Implements Interval Consensus Model (ICM) interval-valued responses using ‘Stan’ ‘Bayesian’ estimation (Kloft et al., 2024 doi:10.31234/osf.io/dzvw2). Provides ILR/SLR transformations, simplex conversions, model fitting via fit_icm(), visualization functions. Includes quantifiers example dataset.
